author: Clemmie Fieldsend
title: Celebrity hotspot Elounda in Crete is Europe's best kept secret - for now at least
text:
Keep it to yourself, but in a corner of the Greek island of Crete lies a former fishing town called Elounda.
With the Aegean sea sparkling at its shores and a backdrop of arid mountain crags, picked over by daredevil goats with clinking bells, this sleepy town is a little gem.
The high-fliers of Greece – and those in the know – like to get away from it all in the luxurious surroundings of little-known Elounda, which sits on a coastline peppered with hidden coves and a light dusting of swanky hotels.
Its fame is starting to spread, though: Leonardo DiCaprio has visited while Lady Gaga spent a fortnight lounging by a pool.
But you don’t have to be famous to be treated like a star here – as we found when we checked in at the Elounda Breeze Hotel, an hour’s drive from ­Heraklion airport.
It was like arriving at a small village where everyone was already our friend.
The hotel has recently been renovated but it still has all the charm of a ­traditional Cretan hotel: shining white and cool blue ­buildings, lush shady foliage and explosions of vibrant bougainvillea flowers just crying out to be my new selfie background.
Little gem: The Elounda coast
It was impossible not to feel instantly relaxed, not least because the staff couldn’t do enough for us. We were greeted by a live band, champagne and nibbles with a ­traditional Greek dance to get involved with (but don’t worry, you don’t have to!).
Breakfast is ­extensive, the dinner buffet has a different theme each evening – options while we were there included Italian, French and Mexican – and there are weekly barbecue nights. Some rooms have views of the gardens, others of the sea or mountains – but all vistas are idyllic.
There’s no danger of getting bored either. There are two large pools (each with a private bar), tennis and basketball courts, a play park for the kids, a spa, a traditional blue and white chapel and a theatre, plus bars exclusively for guests. Oh, and did I mention the hotel’s private beach?
We could have passed the week without leaving the resort but it’s worth getting out.
The main town, a 20-minute walk away or five minutes by car, is a quaint port decorated with palm trees, old stone and white buildings and churches. Small fishing boats still bob in and out of the harbour with their daily catch and it’s a perfect place to stop and sip a glass of ouzo on the front, people-watching.
The Island: A full moon over Spinalonga
There are award-winning restaurants too. We loved Ferryman, a great place to try traditional dishes like dakos (tomatoes, cheese, bread and oil all mixed together to let the flavours infuse) or freshly-caught fish.
We also found time for a bit of culture on the island of Spinalonga.
This former leper colony, just off-shore in the Gulf of Elounda, is the setting for Victoria Hislop’s debut novel The Island. Take your sun hat though – there’s not much shade.
And if you enjoy your retail therapy, it’s worth taking the 30-minute drive south to Agios Nikolaos.
What was so refreshing was to see the locals taking great pride in their town, and as Elounda is still low on the tourist count, visitors receive such a warm welcome it makes it all the harder to leave.
Catch it quick – while it stays that way.
Travel File Must see: Make sure you visit the ancient archaeological site of Knossos.
Book it: An all-inclusive stay at Elounda Breeze (April to October) starts at €33pp (£25) per night for two in a sea view double, or from €44pp (£30) for two in a suite. vitahotels.gr
Getting there: easyJet flies to Heraklion with return fares from £57 in April. easyjet.com
More info: visitgreece.gr/en/greek_islands/crete
